body.p: Governor George C. Wallace of Alabama spoke to an audience which showed mixed emo­ tion at Johns Hopkins University last Saturday. He was a guest of the Young Democratic Club of Hopkins. Outside Shriver Hall wherethegovernorspoke before a capacity audience, were some 50 pickets from Hopkins, Goucher, and various local or­ ganizations. Some people were handing out mimeographed attacks on the governor, and a pamphlet supporing the civil rights bill. Inside the auditorium there were more civil rights advocates handing out leaflets that said "Let’s greet Wallace in silence,” and asked the audience not to applaud, boo, or react in any way to the governor’s address. When Governor Wallace walked out on the stage, he was greeted by a round of applause as about half the people there chose to disre­ gard the leaflets. His security men were scattered throughout the auditorium, and reporters from the local newspapers took their seats in the front row. Flashbulbs exploded as thegovemor walked up to the microphone The governor opened his speech by stating that he would like to present "a different image of people in my part of the country than what you read in the local press.” He first dispelled the press-created image of the bigoted southerner by pointing out that his administration has done more to further the cause of racial equality than any other administration in Alabama history. He added that he had once served on the Board of Directors of Tuskegee Institute, the world re­ nouned Negro college in Alabama, and that his administration has donated over $700,000 to this private institution. His administration had also undertaken the most far-reaching school building program in the state’s history, which includes 26 junior colleges and trade schools for his rapidly industrializing state: "Hy the middle of next year,” said the governor, ’’every student in Alabama, regardless of his race, will be within busdistanceof a junior college or trade school” He then began discussing the civil rights bill ( H. R 7152), a bill he described as "the gravest political issue facing this country in years.” He quoted two past presidents of the American Bar Association who described the bill as "ten per cent Civil Rights ninety per cent an extension of the federal executive power created at the ex­ pense of individuals, states, and municipalities.” He pointed out that he was not here to attack personalities, but only to debate the issues. He noted that his opponents have not come out with any statements on the civil rights bill—the main issue in the campaign, but instead have resorted to character-assassination. "If the civil rights bill is a good as they say it is,” asked the governor, referring to the bill’s supporters "why won’t they face me on statewide television and radio to debate the issue?” He added that according to the press, any­ body opposed to the bill is a racist, a bigot, is prqudiced and immoral. "It’s the bill that’s im­ moral,” said the governor. "Whenever the fed­ eral government can tell you who to sell your house to, and can jail you without a jury trial if you fail to do what they tell you—that’s immoral.”
